citation.article-title: Ramlibacter tataouinensis gen. nov., sp. nov., and Ramlibacter henchirensis sp. nov., cyst-producing bacteria isolated from subdesert soil in Tunisia.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Ramlibacter gen. nov.
Ramlibacter (Ram.li.bac′ter. N.L. n. ramlis from Arabic raml sand; M.L. masc. n. bacter rod; N.L. masc. n. Ramlibacter rod isolated from sandy soil).
Small yellow-orange colonies (diameter 0·1–0·5 mm on TSA/10 plates after 15 days at 30 °C).
Pleomorphic, ranging from rods (vegetative cells) to coccoid cells (cysts).
Vegetative cells are long thin rods (mean dimensions: 3 μm in length and 0·2 μm in diameter) that form cysts (0·8–0·9 μm in diameter).
Polyhydroxyalkanoate is present in cytoplasm of rods and cysts.
Cell division occurs in cysts.
Cysts are desiccation-resistant.
Gram-negative.
Catalase-positive and oxidase-positive.
Vegetative cells motile by gliding.
Flagella absent in vegetative and cyst cells.
Aerobic chemo-organotrophic.
Slow-growing in optimal conditions.
Optimal pH and temperature for growth: 7·5 and 30 °C.
Weak growth at 37 °C.
Growth factors required.
Positive for reduction of nitrate to nitrite and aesculin hydrolysis (β-glucosidase) but negative for denitrification, indole production and arginine dihydrolase and urease activities.
Arabinose, mannose, mannitol, N-acetylglucosamine, maltose, gluconate, caprate, adipate, malate, citrate and phenylacetate not assimilated.
The type species of the genus is Ramlibacter tataouinensis.
